qas.question: Southampton's history of administrative independence dates back to the reign of which king?
What was the annual fee paid by the burgesses of Southampton for the rights of custom and toll laid out in the charter of 1199?
In the 1100s, the port of Southampton included everything between Lymington and what area?
Under what king was a charter granted in 1446/7 that separated Southampton and Portsmouth from Hampshire?
What date was the charter regarding Southampton's tax farm signed at Orival?

context: Southampton as a Port and city has had a long history of administrative independence of the surrounding County; as far back as the reign of <a0_0>King John<a0_0/> the town and its port were removed from the writ of the King's Sheriff in Hampshire and the rights of custom and toll were granted by the King to the burgesses of Southampton over the port of Southampton and the Port of Portsmouth; this tax farm was granted for an annual fee of <a1_0>£200<a1_0/> in the charter dated at Orival on <a4_0>29 June 1199<a4_0/>. The definition of the port of Southampton was apparently broader than today and embraced all of the area between Lymington and <a2_0>Langstone<a2_0/>. The corporation had resident representatives in Newport, Lymington and Portsmouth. By a charter of <a3_0>Henry VI<a3_0/>, granted on 9 March 1446/7 (25+26 Hen. VI, m. 32), the mayor, bailiffs and burgesses of the towns and ports of Southampton and Portsmouth became a County incorporate and separate from Hampshire.
